Incorrect: Patients with PSGN typically present with edema, hypertension, and cola-colored urine 2-3 weeks after streptococcal infections and urinalysis showing proteinuria, hematuria, and red blood cells casts which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of hematuria, hemoptysis, and malaise for 3 weeks. There is no associated fever, joint pain, rash, or recent infection. Past medical is non-contributory. Family history is negative for renal disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals mild periorbital edema and is otherwise normal. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following would confirm the diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Sodium      140 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride      100 mEq/L    
 Creatinine      0.9 mg/dL    
 Antibodies    
 Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody (anti-GBM)     Negative    
 Anti-neutrophilic cytoplasmic autoantibody (ANCA) screen     Positive     
 c-ANCA     Positive    
 p-ANCA     Negative    
 Urine     
 Erythrocytes     100/hpf    
 Leukocytes     2/hpf    
 Urine specific gravity     1.010    
 Protein       +1     
 Red blood cell casts     Positive
questions.solution:
This child presents with hematuria and hemoptysis, without recent infection or hearing loss, and has a positive cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (c-ANCA). These findings are suggestive of ANCA-associated glomerulonephritis, most likely granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). When feasible, a renal biopsy should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis before initiating long-term immunosuppressive therapy.       

Nephritic syndrome should be suspected in patients with hematuria, dark (cola- or tea-colored) urine, and decreased urine output. Physical exam may reveal hypertension and edema. The diagnostic workup begins with urinalysis and microscopy. Findings supportive of nephritic syndrome include hematuria, proteinuria, red blood cells, and red blood cell casts. Additional evaluation includes serum creatinine, complement levels, antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer, serum IgA, and galactose-deficient IgA1. Autoantibody testing should include c-ANCA, p-ANCA, anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibody, antinuclear antibody (ANA), anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA), and anti-Smith antibody.        

The clinical history and associated symptoms help refine the differential. Patients with nephritic syndrome and hemoptysis should raise concern for pulmonary-renal syndrome such as ANCA-associated glomerulonephritis or anti-GBM disease. Confirmation of ANCA-associated glomerulonephritis requires renal biopsy, which typically shows segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis with minimal or absent immune complex deposition.  

Option Analysis

❌ A 24-hour urine collection for protein. :
Incorrect: While this test can quantify proteinuria and assess glomerular dysfunction, it is not necessary for diagnosis in a patient with active urinary sediment and systemic signs suggestive of glomerulonephritis. A renal biopsy is indicated to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment. 
✅ Renal biopsy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum immunoglobulin A (IgA) level :
Incorrect: Serum immunoglobulin A level testing is useful in the diagnosis of IgA nephropathy, which typically presents with hematuria following a viral upper respiratory infection. The history of hemoptysis, hematuria, and laboratory findings in this case are more consistent with ANCA-associated glomerulonephritis. Renal biopsy should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer  :
Incorrect: Anti-streptolysin O titer testing is helpful for the diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which typically follows a recent streptococcal infection. However, the findings in this patient are more consistent with ANCA-associated glomerulonephritis, and renal biopsy is indicated to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Genetic testing  :
Incorrect: Genetic testing is used to diagnose conditions such as Alport syndrome, which is typically associated with a family history of renal disease, hearing loss, and ocular findings. Hemoptysis is not a typical feature.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents to the office for evaluation of vomiting, oliguria, and gross hematuria for two days. There has been no fever, recent infection, hemoptysis, or joint pain. Past medical history is significant for congenital hepatitis C infection. Family and surgical histories are noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 139/83 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, edema of the lower extremities is noted. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Laboratory evaluation shows preserved renal function, with low complement C3 and C4 levels and a negative antinuclear antibody (ANA). Renal biopsy shows basement membrane thickening with a “tram-track” appearance and mesangial hypercellularity. Which of the following is most appropriate in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This child has membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), presenting with oliguria and gross hematuria in the setting of chronic hepatitis C infection. Laboratory evaluation shows preserved renal function with hematuria. Renal biopsy demonstrates a “tram-track” pattern, confirming the diagnosis. The most appropriate next step is to manage the patient's hypertension, including administration of captopril.        

Nephritic syndrome typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria, red blood cell casts, oliguria, hypertension, and sometimes uremia. In the absence of respiratory infection, hearing loss, or hemoptysis, immune complex-mediated proliferative glomerulonephritis should be considered, especially in the setting of chronic infections such as hepatitis B or C, or autoimmune conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus. MPGN is often associated with low complement C3 and C4 levels. Renal biopsy with immunofluorescence distinguishes MPGN from diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN). Mesangial hypercellularity and basement membrane thickening with a “tram-track” appearance are characteristic of MPGN, whereas DPGN more commonly shows a “wire-loop” appearance of glomerular capillary walls.       

Treatment of nephritic syndrome is primarily supportive unless a treatable underlying cause is identified (e.g. hepatitis C). Antihypertensives, typically an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), are used in patients with elevated blood pressure despite salt and fluid restriction. Loop diuretics may be given to manage volume overload. Corticosteroids are sometimes used to reduce inflammation, though immunosuppressive therapy is generally reserved for rapidly progressing diseases. In cases of end-stage renal disease, dialysis may be necessary.   

Option Analysis

❌ Protein restriction :
Incorrect: Protein restriction is generally reserved for patients with advanced chronic kidney disease. This patient has membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis with preserved renal function. Dietary protein restriction is not indicated at this stage.  
✅ Captopril:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cyclophosphamide:
Incorrect: Cyclophosphamide is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain immune-mediated glomerular diseases. However, in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis associated with hepatitis C, immunosuppressive therapy is typically avoided, particularly if the underlying infection has not been treated. 
❌ Long-term dialysis:
Incorrect: Dialysis is reserved for patients with end-stage renal disease. This patient does not show evidence of severe renal dysfunction and does not meet criteria for long-term dialysis. 
❌ Kidney transplantation referral:
Incorrect: Kidney transplantation is indicated for patients with irreversible end-stage renal disease. At this stage, the patient’s renal function is preserved, and there is no indication for transplant evaluation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue and irritability over the past week. The patient’s appetite has also decreased over this period. The caregivers report no fevers, rash, joint pain, dyspnea, abdominal pain, or dysuria. The child is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 100/min, respiratory rate is 25/min, blood pressure 105/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Laboratory analysis shows proteinuria, elevated serum lipids, and low serum albumin. Which of the following additional clinical findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with fatigue and irritability, and laboratory studies reveal proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia; these findings are consistent with nephrotic syndrome. Among the listed clinical findings, periorbital edema is most strongly associated with nephrotic syndrome and is often one of the earliest physical exam signs.       

Children with nephrotic syndrome frequently present with nonspecific symptoms such as malaise, headache, fatigue, or irritability. As the disease progresses, edema typically begins in the periorbital region and may spread to the lower extremities or progress to generalized anasarca. Severe volume overload can lead to pulmonary edema and respiratory distress. Characteristic laboratory findings include significant proteinuria, low serum albumin, and elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels. Less common features include hypertension, hematuria, intravascular volume depletion, or complications such as infection, thromboembolism, or pancreatitis.   



Option Analysis

❌ Cola-colored urine:
Incorrect: This patient has multiple laboratory findings consistent with nephrotic syndrome, including proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Cola-colored urine is associated with nephritic syndrome, not nephrotic syndrome.  
❌ Cardiomegaly:
Incorrect: Cardiomegaly, or an enlarged heart, is typically associated with heart failure. The laboratory findings of proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia in this case are more consistent with nephrotic syndrome. 
❌ Cracked lips and conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: These findings are seen in Kawasaki disease, which presents with prolonged fever and mucocutaneous inflammation, not nephrotic-range proteinuria or hypoalbuminemia. This patient’s findings are more consistent with nephrotic syndrome. 
✅ Periorbital edema:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent streptococcal infection:
Incorrect: Recent streptococcal infection can lead to poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a nephritic process marked by hematuria and hypertension. However, this patient’s laboratory findings of proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia are more consistent with nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy patient presents to the pediatrician for follow-up regarding treatment of nephrotic syndrome. The patient was diagnosed with suspected minimal change disease 6 weeks ago and is currently being treated with prednisone. At today's visit, the caregiver reports that the child has been doing well, with a noted decrease in swelling. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a child in no apparent distress, with no periorbital edema noted. The patient's urine protein-to-creatinine ratios over the past three days are 0.15 mg/mg, 0.12 mg/mg, and 0.11 mg/mg. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient has a known diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome, most likely minimal change disease based on age and clinical response. Most affected children are steroid-sensitive, defined as achieving resolution of proteinuria or a urine protein-to-creatinine ratio below 0.2 on three separate occasions within 4 to 6 weeks of starting glucocorticoid therapy. These patients should continue glucocorticoid treatment for 8 to 12 weeks, followed by reassessment for remission.       

Treatment of pediatric nephrotic syndrome depends on the underlying etiology, which can be categorized by whether the presentation indicates a renal biopsy (i.e. age under 1 year or over 12 years, significantly elevated serum creatinine, gross hematuria, or marked hypertension). Patients who do not initially require biopsy are most likely to have minimal change disease and should be started on empiric glucocorticoids. Those who respond should complete a full 8- to 12-week course and be monitored for relapse. Patients who do not respond after 4 to 6 weeks are considered steroid-resistant, which typically warrants a renal biopsy and referral to pediatric nephrology to evaluate for alternative causes, such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis or membranous nephropathy. Treatment options in steroid-resistant cases may include calcineurin inhibitors or renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitors (RAASi).   

Option Analysis

❌ Addition of cyclophosphamide:
Incorrect: Cyclophosphamide should be considered for pediatric patients with nephrotic syndrome and frequent relapses or membranous nephropathy. This patient appears to be responding to steroid therapy and should be continued on glucocorticoids. 
❌ Addition of cyclosporine:
Incorrect: Calcineurin inhibitors are used in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome or in certain histologic subtypes such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. This patient is responding well to steroid treatment. 
❌ Pediatric nephrology referral:
Incorrect: Pediatric nephrology referral should be considered for patients with steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome or for patients who present with indications requiring a renal biopsy. This patient is demonstrating clinical and laboratory improvement on first-line therapy. 
✅ Glucocorticoid therapy for 8-12 more weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cessation of glucocorticoid therapy:
Incorrect: Although the patient is improving, steroid therapy should not be discontinued abruptly. A full course of treatment with gradual tapering is recommended to reduce the risk of relapse.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department after noticing blood in his urine and experiencing dysuria and urinary frequency for one day There is no penile discharge, and he is not sexually active. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing without abdominal or flank tenderness to palpation. Genital examination is within normal limits. Urinalysis shows blood and leukocyte esterase. Five months ago, a computed tomography (CT) scan was done after the patient was hit by a car while riding his bike. The scan showed normal-sized kidneys with an 8 mm sharply demarcated, smooth-walled cyst in the left kidney without septa or solid components. At that time, he had no significant injuries, and his basic metabolic panel and urinalysis were normal. Antibiotics are started, and a urine culture is sent. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Genetic testing for polycystic kidney disease

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with symptoms and urinalysis consistent with a urinary tract infection, which is treated appropriately. He also has an incidental finding of an 8 mm sharply demarcated, smooth-walled cyst in the left kidney without septa or solid components and normal-sized kidneys bilaterally. These findings are consistent with a simple renal cyst. No further testing is needed to evaluate this cyst.

Patients with kidney cysts should have a serum basic metabolic panel to assess for renal dysfunction. Urinalysis should also be ordered to look for hematuria and proteinuria. While simple renal cysts are not associated with lab abnormalities, acquired renal cystic disease, like autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) and autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (ADTKD), can be associated with elevated creatinine. In cases of medullary sponge kidney disease or ADPKD, there may be hematuria on urinalysis. Patients with medullary sponge kidney disease should undergo intravenous pyelogram or computed tomographic urography to further assess the cystic disease. If ADTKD is suspected, patients should have serum uric acid tested and be assessed for UMOD or MUC1 mutations.
   

Simple renal cyst (Courtesy of Statdx):
Longitudinal US of the left kidney shows an exophytic typical simple cortical cyst with no internal echoes, calcification, or solid component.   

Option Analysis

✅ No further testing required :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Repeat renal ultrasound in 3 months :
Incorrect: This patient has a simple renal cyst on ultrasound without concerning features and a urinary tract infection. Repeat ultrasound is not required. 
❌ Intravenous pyelogram:
Incorrect: Intravenous pyelogram can be used in the workup of medullary sponge kidney disease. This patient has no evidence of kidney stones or medullary cysts on ultrasound to suggest this diagnosis. The hematuria is likely due to a urinary tract infection. 
❌ Genetic testing for polycystic kidney disease:
Incorrect: Polycystic kidney disease usually presents with features such as flank pain, abdominal pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, and elevated blood pressure. This patient has normal-sized kidneys and a first episode of a urinary tract infection. 
❌ Renal biopsy:
Incorrect: Renal biopsy may be indicated in cases of parenchymal renal disease, such as unexplained severe acute kidney injury, or for staging of lupus nephritis. This patient has simple cysts, and renal biopsy is inappropriate.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic to establish care. He was recently seen in the emergency department for abdominal pain, which has since resolved. CT scan performed at that time showed bilateral kidney cysts. Last week, the patient moved heavy boxes and has had low back pain radiating to the flanks since then, which worsens with exercise. He was treated eight months ago for a urinary tract infection that resolved with antibiotics. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 136/86 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is no costovertebral angle tenderness to percussion and kidneys are not palpable. The abdominal exam is within normal limits. There is bilateral paraspinal muscle tenderness in the lumbar spine. The left first toe is warm, swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following indicates the need for genetic testing in this patient?

choices.text: Monoarticular arthritis of the first metatarsal joint of the foot

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an incidental finding of cystic kidney disease. On physical exam, he has evidence of monoarticular arthritis in the big left toe, which is consistent with gout. Cystic kidney disease and gout are seen in patients with autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (ADTKD). Genetic testing for UMOD and MUC1 mutations is necessary to diagnose ADTKD. Patients with cystic kidney disease and gout usually have a mutation in UMOD.

Kidney cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can be found in the cortex and/or medulla. They can occur as primary lesions, acquired due to underlying medical disease, or inherited. Certain cystic kidney diseases are associated with loss of renal function and chronic kidney disease. The most common types of cystic kidney disease are simple renal cysts, medullary sponge kidney disease, acquired renal cystic disease, autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), and ADTKD. Cysts are typically seen on ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or computed tomography (CT). A combination of the patient’s history, physical examination findings, and laboratory studies (e.g., renal function studies, and urinalysis) will typically help differentiate which cystic kidney disease is present. Genetic testing is needed to make the diagnosis of ADTKD.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Monoarticular arthritis of the first metatarsal joint of the foot :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Elevated blood pressure:
Incorrect: Elevated blood pressure is a nonspecific finding that can be seen in various conditions, including autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which typically does not necessitate genetic testing for diagnosis. Hypertension can also be seen in autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease, the combination of early-onset gout and cystic kidney disease is indicative of this disease. The diagnosis requires genetic testing to confirm. 
❌ Flank pain :
Incorrect: Flank pain may be present in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which does not require genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis. However, in this patient, the flank pain seems more likely related to a recent lower back muscular injury. 
❌ Non-palpable kidneys:
Incorrect: Kidneys may be palpable in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease and are not palpable in other cystic kidney diseases. Lack of palpable kidneys would not be an indication of a specific type of cystic kidney disease. 
❌ Prior urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Recurrent urinary tract infections and kidney stones may suggest medullary sponge kidney disease or autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. This patient had one episode of a urinary tract infection that resolved, and the presence of monoarticular arthritis consistent with gout is more suggestive of a diagnosis of autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease, which requires genetic testing to confirm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office for right flank pain, dysuria, and blood in the urine. The patient has a family history of kidney disease in multiple relatives. Her past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 152/96 mm Hg. On physical exam, there is mild suprapubic tenderness and mild tenderness at the bilateral flanks. In-office urinalysis is positive for hematuria and leukocyte esterase. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on kidney ultrasound?

choices.text: Enlarged kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts
Normal-sized kidneys with sharply demarcated, smooth-walled cortical cysts
Small kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts

questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral flank pain, hypertension, hematuria, and a urinary tract infection. Additionally, she has a strong family history of kidney disease. The most likely diagnosis is autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Findings on ultrasound in patients with ADPKD include enlarged kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts bilaterally.

Kidney cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can be found in the cortex and/or medulla of one or both kidneys. They can occur as primary lesions, acquired due to underlying medical disease, or inherited. The most common types of conditions in which renal cysts are seen are simple renal cysts, medullary sponge kidney disease, acquired renal cystic disease, ADPKD, and autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (ADTKD). After a thorough history and physical are performed, ultrasound imaging should be performed to assist with differentiating between these conditions.

Patients with ADPKD will often present with recurrent urinary tract infections, hematuria, and flank pain (due to the large cyst burden and the resultant kidney enlargement). Elevated blood pressure is a common finding, and the kidneys may be palpable on exam due to their enlargement. Serum testing may show elevated creatinine, and urinalysis can indicate proteinuria and hematuria.   

Option Analysis

✅ Enlarged kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Normal-sized kidneys with sharply demarcated, smooth-walled cortical cysts:
Incorrect: These ultrasound findings are consistent with simple renal cysts, which, depending on size and characteristics, may require no further monitoring or periodic imaging surveillance. This patient has a family history of kidney disease, flank pain, urinary tract infection, and hypertension consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 
❌ Small kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts:
Incorrect: These ultrasound findings suggest an acquired renal cystic disease, such as that seen with advanced chronic kidney disease and patients on hemodialysis. This patient has a family history of kidney disease, flank pain, urinary tract infection, and hypertension consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 
❌ Multiple medullary cysts:
Incorrect: This ultrasound finding would be consistent with autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease in a patient with elevated serum creatinine and gout.  
❌ Multiple medullary cysts and nephrocalcinosis:
Incorrect: These ultrasound findings suggest medullary sponge kidney disease, for which computed tomography or intravenous pyelogram should be performed. While this disease may present with hematuria and flank pain, this patient’s elevated blood pressure and strong family history instead suggest autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the primary care physician for a follow-up appointment after a recent hospitalization. Five-days ago, the patient presented to the emergency room with left flank pain accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. She was subsequently diagnosed with nephrolithiasis and treated with conservative measurements. Urinalysis performed at the time of admission revealed the following:

Retrieved from:

The patient is extremely worried about recurrence and would like to know how she can prevent future episodes. In addition to recommending increased fluid intake, which of the following would be the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: Add high dose vitamin C to your diet

questions.solution:
Renal stone disease (nephrolithiasis) is a common condition that more frequently affects men than women. Stones are formed when risk factors lead to supersaturation of the urine, formation of crystals, and aggregation into clinically detectable and symptomatic stones. Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type, accounting for 80% of all stones. They present as dumbbell-shaped or envelope-shaped crystals on urinalysis.  

High sodium intake is thought to enhance calcium excretion and increase the risk for kidney stones. In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), calcium handling is mainly dependent on sodium. High dietary sodium induces relative hypervolemia. This in turn diminishes the efficacy of sodium and water reabsorption in the PCT. Concurrently, calcium reabsorption, which occurs in the PCT and is passively coupled with sodium and water, is also reduced. As a result, urine calcium concentrations increase.



Option Analysis

❌ Reduce your dietary calcium intake:
Incorrect: Calcium oxalate stones formation is associated with hypercalciuria (high calcium in the urine), not high dietary calcium. Interestingly, although counter-intuitive, high dietary calcium reduces the risk of stone formation. The exact mechanism is unclear but may be related to increased oxalate ingestion in calcium-containing foods, which binds calcium in the gut, thus reducing calcium absorption. By contrast, calcium supplements appear to slightly increase the risk of stone formation.
✅ Reduce your dietary sodium intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increase your dietary oxalate intake:
Incorrect: Oxalate is generated from the metabolism of glycine, hydroxyproline, and vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and is found in many types of food. It can also be produced from endogenous metabolism. Oxalate is eventually excreted in the urine. High dietary oxalate is associated with increased risk for calcium oxalate stone formation.
❌ Add high dose vitamin C to your diet:
Incorrect: Excess vitamin C increases the risk of developing stones since the metabolism of vitamin C yields oxalate, which is excreted via urine. Oxalate can then bind with calcium, forming calcium oxalate stones.
❌ Reduce your dietary potassium intake:
Incorrect: A higher, not lower, dietary potassium intake is associated with reduced risk of stones. The exact mechanism is unclear, but it has been suggested that higher potassium levels decrease urinary calcium excretion.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset left back pain and hematuria. The patient states that since the early morning, she has been having intense pain in the left mid-back that comes in waves. She has no nausea or vomiting. Past medical history includes hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. The patient is currently in pain. Urinalysis findings are shown below. Non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates a 2 mm obstructing stone mid-ureter on the left.  Which of the following historical or physical exam findings would be most consistent with the underlying diagnosis?

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms and urinalysis findings that are concerning for nephrolithiasis, which is confirmed with non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis that shows a renal stone on the left. Left flank (or costovertebral angle) tenderness would be an expected physical examination finding.

Nephrolithiasis, also known as renal calculi or renal (or kidney) stones, is a painful condition where crystals form in the kidney that potentially lead to urinary tract obstruction.  Renal stones usually form when urine becomes oversaturated with minerals and salts, including calcium, oxalate, and uric acid. Common renal stone types include calcium oxalate-, calcium phosphate-, uric acid-, cystine-, and struvite stones. Patients classically present with the acute onset of flank pain, which may radiate to the groin. Patients may have associated hematuria, dysuria urgency, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination may reveal unilateral flank or costovertebral angle tenderness. Patients often appear uncomfortable from the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Left flank tenderness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Suprapubic tenderness:
Incorrect:  Suprapubic tenderness is typically suggestive of bladder inflammation or other lower urinary tract pathology, such as cystitis. This patient’s urinalysis is not indicative of an infection, and CT shows a left kidney stone.  
❌ High fever:
Incorrect:  Fever can be seen with renal stones, it typically indicates pyelonephritis, or infection of the kidney, which can be a complication of renal stones. However, there is no infection evident on urinalysis and there is no evidence of pyelonephritis on CT.  
❌ Bradycardia:
Incorrect:   Bradycardia is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis. Tachycardia is more likely to be seen as a consequence of pain.  
❌ Abdominal distension:
Incorrect:   Abdominal distention is not a typical finding in nephrolithiasis, however, it may be seen if there is associated nausea and vomiting, which this patient does not have.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right flank pain for the past 6 hours and 3 days of dysuria and urinary frequency. The patient has a past medical history of recurrent urinary tract infections, hypertension, and diabetes. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 176/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 101/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable and is vomiting into an emesis basin. She is started on IV normal saline, IV ketorolac, and ondansetron. A CBC and basic metabolic panel are pending. Urinalysis findings are shown below. Non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows an obstructing stone in the right ureter. What type of crystals are most likely to be identified on urine microscopy?

choices.text: Amorphous wedge-shaped crystals in rosette pattern

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms and physical examination findings consistent with nephrolithiasis and a concurrent urinary tract infection. Additionally, the patient’s urine pH is > 8, making this likely to be a struvite stone. On urine microscopy, struvite stones appear as coffin lid-shaped crystals.

Nephrolithiasis, also known as renal calculi or renal stones, is a painful condition where crystals form in the kidneys. Common renal stone types include calcium oxalate-, calcium phosphate-, uric acid-, cystine-, and struvite stones. Struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones are strongly associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs) with urease-producing organisms (e.g. Proteus species). Hence, they are sometimes called “infection stones.” Struvite stones form within the lumen of the renal pelvis and can extend into one or more of the renal calyces. They are typically large and are at risk of causing obstruction. Therefore, urological consultation for stone removal is necessary to prevent complications.

Identifying the stone type can assist in determining treatment and prevention. Renal stone composition analysis; urine microscopy; and 24-hour urine collection for pH, calcium, oxalate, citrate, uric acid, and phosphorus should be performed. The following table shows the findings and treatments associated with the different types of renal stones.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Coffin lid-shaped crystals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hexagon-shaped crystals:
Incorrect: Hexagon-shaped crystals are seen in patients with cystine stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.  
❌ Rhomboid-shaped crystals:
Incorrect: Rhomboid-shaped crystals are seen in patients with uric acid stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.
❌ Amorphous wedge-shaped crystals in rosette pattern:
Incorrect: Amorphous wedge-shaped crystals in a rosette pattern are seen in patients with calcium-phosphate stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.  
❌ Envelope-shaped crystals:
Incorrect: Envelope or dumbbell-shaped crystals are seen in patients with calcium oxalate stones. This patient’s clinical picture of nephrolithiasis with recurrent UTIs is more consistent with struvite stones.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset hematuria and left flank pain. The patient has a history of recurrent kidney stones and states these symptoms feel similar. One year ago, her right kidney was removed due to injuries sustained in a motor vehicle accident. The patient does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 190/87 mmHg, heart rate is 88 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and in mild distress. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The patient has left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness, and the rest of the abdominal examination is unremarkable. Initial laboratory studies and a urinalysis are shown below. Post-void residual (PVR) is <100 mL. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 1 cm stone at the left ureteropelvic junction with upstream hydronephrosis; the right kidney is absent. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Sodium      140 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride     97 mEq/L    
 BUN     47 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      2.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.3 mg/dL six months ago)    
 Albumin      3.2 g/dL    
 Urinalysis    
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Blood     Positive        
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative        
 Nitrites     Negative        
 Leukocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     100/hpf    
 Casts     None

choices.text: Urology consultation for ureteral stent placement

questions.solution:
This patient has a single functioning kidney and presents with laboratory evidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) and obstructive nephrolithiasis on CT imaging. Given the stone size and the AKI, the next step is to consult urology for ureteral stent placement, lithotripsy, or surgical stone removal.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) refers to a sudden decline in kidney function that leads to electrolyte imbalances, extracellular dysregulation, and accumulation of nitrogenous wastes such as ammonia and uric acid. Postrenal AKI occurs when urinary flow is blocked anywhere in the urinary tract, whether in the upper tract (i.e. ureters) or the lower tract (i.e. bladder or urethra). In cases of nephrolithiasis, obstruction must typically involve both kidneys to cause AKI unless only one functioning kidney remains, as in this case.

Management of postrenal AKI depends on the cause and location of the obstruction. In general, an upper urinary tract obstruction (e.g., obstructive nephrolithiasis, malignancy, external compression) can be managed with ureteral stent placement to bypass the obstruction, lithotripsy to fragment an obstructing stone, or surgery. Lower urinary tract obstruction is managed first with catheterization and then by addressing the underlying condition (e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia, bladder tumor).

Option Analysis

✅ Urology consultation for ureteral stent placement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supportive measures only:
Incorrect: Supportive measures alone (e.g., intravenous fluids, analgesia, and medical expulsive therapy) would be insufficient in a patient with a solitary kidney and a large obstructing ureteropelvic junction stone resulting in postrenal acute kidney injury. Urology consultation for decompression is required.
❌ Foley catheter placement:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of obstructive nephrolithiasis causing postrenal acute kidney injury. Foley catheter placement is not indicated given the obstruction is in the upper urinary tract. Instead, urology consultation for decompression is required.
❌ Intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics would be indicated if this patient were to have evidence of an associated urinary tract infection. This patient's urinalysis is only notable for blood, as expected with a large kidney stone. Instead, urology consultation for decompression is required.
❌ Suprapubic catheter placement:
Incorrect: A suprapubic catheter is used for lower urinary tract obstruction or urinary retention after a failed Foley catheter placement; it would not relieve an upper tract obstruction due to nephrolithiasis. Instead, urology consultation for decompression is required.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left flank pain radiating to the groin. The pain started two hours ago, is sharp, and is rated by the patient as a 10/10. The patient has hematuria but no dysuria or urgency. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows no costovertebral angle tenderness. Plain radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 4 mm calcified density at the level of the lower left sacrum, just above the level of the vesicoureteric junction. This patient’s groin pain is most likely referred from the involvement of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with flank pain radiating to the groin and radiographic evidence of an opacity in the pelvis, along the course of ureter, is consistent with ureteric colic/calculus.    

A ureteric calculus is the presence of a solid stone in the urinary tract, formed from minerals within the urine. These can obstruct urinary flow, causing renal colic (an acute and severe loin pain) and haematuria. There are three locations where the ureters are at their narrowest and, therefore, where a stone is more likely to become stuck: 
  •  Ureteropelvic junction 
  •  Pelvic brim 
  •  Where the ureter enters the bladder 
Nervous supply to the ureters is delivered via the renal, testicular/ovarian, and hypogastric plexuses. Sensory fibers from the ureters enter the spinal cord at T11-L2 with ureteric pain referred to those dermatomal areas. 
  •  Pain from upper ureteral stones tends to radiate to the flank and lumbar areas.  
  •  Mid-ureteral calculi cause pain that radiates anteriorly and caudally.  
  •  Distal ureteral stones cause pain that tends to radiate into the groin or testicle in the male or labia majora in the female because the pain is referred from the ilioinguinal (L1) or genitofemoral nerves (L1-L2). 


Option Analysis

❌ Subcostal :
Incorrect: The subcostal nerve is the anterior division of the twelfth thoracic nerve. It communicates with the iliohypogastric nerve and gives a branch to the pyramidalis muscle. It also gives off a lateral cutaneous branch that supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the hip. Its involvement would not cause groin pain.  
❌ Iliohypogastric :
Incorrect: The iliohypogastric nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies sensation to skin over the lateral gluteal and hypogastric regions and motor to the internal oblique and transverse abdominal muscles. It’s involvement would not cause groin pain seen in this patient.  
✅ Ilioinguinal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sciatic :
Incorrect: Sciatic nerve pain typically affects one or more regions in the low back, thigh, leg, and foot but not the groin.  
❌ Pelvic splanchnic:
Incorrect: Pelvic splanchnic nerves are splanchnic nerves that arise from sacral spinal nerves S2, S3,  and S4 to provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut, urinary bladder, and sphincter.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of urinary retention. The patient states he was last able to void 14 hours ago. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, osteoarthritis and hyperlipidemia. Medications include amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. The patient occasionally takes ibuprofen for joint pain.  The patient's last A1C was 5.7. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 167/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 99/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears uncomfortable, and abdominal exam is significant for  suprapubic fullness. Rectal exam is significant for an enlarged prostate and normal anal sphincter tone. Bladder scan reveals >1L. Laboratory findings and urinalysis results are detailed below. A foley catheter is placed with immediate relief of symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute urinary retention. He is an older man with an enlarged prostate on exam suggesting that benign prostatic hyperplasia is the underlying cause of urinary retention.

Urinary retention refers to the inability to voluntarily empty the urinary bladder. It can be acute or chronic, and range from partial to complete urinary retention. Urinary retention has multiple causes including spinal cord compression or injury, medication side effects, urethral obstruction (e.g. BPH), and urinary tract infection.

Patients with urinary retention should be assessed for chronicity of symptoms and should have a detailed history and assessment for neurological red flags such as lower extremity weakness and decreased anal sphincter tone. Patients should be asked about risk factors such as medications (e.g. anticholinergic agents, antipsychotics, opioids), anatomic obstructions (e.g. benign prostatic hyperplasia), diabetes which can cause neurogenic bladder, and urinary tract infection (e.g. dysuria). Once cauda equina syndrome and medications have been excluded, further testing can help determine the underlying cause. The initial evaluation should include a BMP, CBC, PSA, urinalysis, and urine culture.  

Option Analysis

✅ Benign prostatic hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: This patient does not take any medications associated with acute urinary retention.  
❌ Cauda equina syndrome:
Incorrect:  Cauda equina syndrome presents with associated low back pain typically after spinal injury and neurologic deficits such as decreased anal sphincter tone and lower extremity weakness.  
❌ Urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: This patient's symptoms and urinalysis results do not suggest infection. The small blood on UA is likely secondary to foley catheter insertion.  
❌ Autonomic neuropathy:
Incorrect: Uncontrolled diabetes can result in neurogenic bladder and urinary retention. This patient has well controlled DM.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right flank pain, hematuria, and vomiting for the past 10 hours. The patient has a past medical history of obesity, hypertension, and diabetes. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 155/75 mm Hg, heart rate is 111/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. Physical exam reveals right-sided flank tenderness. He is started on IV normal saline, IV ketorolac, and ondansetron.  A CBC and BMP are pending. Urinalysis findings are shown below. A non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 6.5 mm obstructing stone in the mid-ureter on the right side. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value

questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with nephrolithiasis which is confirmed with CT-imaging. Given the size of the stone, the best next step in management is to obtain a urologic consultation. Renal stones that are ≥ 6 mm are unlikely to pass spontaneously. These stones typically require endoscopic removal or extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.

Patients with suspected nephrolithiasis should have a non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to confirm the diagnosis, characterize the size and location of the stone, and determine if hydronephrosis is present. Stones that are <6 mm in size may pass spontaneously. Patients can be sent home on pain medication and instructed to increase fluid intake and strain their urine to collect any stones that pass. They can be prescribed alpha-blockers, like tamsulosin, which can help relax the ureteral smooth muscle and facilitate stone passage. Stones that are ≥ 6 mm in size require urologic consultation for endoscopic removal or extracorporeal lithotripsy.

Regardless of the management strategy, the stone type should be assessed, either from the stone fragments obtained during a urologic procedure or from stones collected in a calculi strainer. 24-hour urine collection should be sent for urinary pH, calcium, oxalate, citrate, uric acid, and phosphorus levels. The information from these studies is used to determine which measures should be taken to prevent future stones. Regardless of the type of stone, all patients with stones should be encouraged to drink enough fluid to dilute urine and maintain a urine output of at least 2.5 liters in 24 hours. In general, a low-sodium diet that is high in fruits and vegetables is recommended to prevent stones. Specific dietary recommendations and medications should be tailored to the type of stones found.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urologic consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Trial of spontaneous passage:
Incorrect: Renal stones that are ≥ 6 mm are unlikely to pass spontaneously. This patient requires urologic consultation for endoscopic removal or extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.  
❌ 24-hour urinary studies:
Incorrect:  24-hour urinary studies are indicated when the renal stone has spontaneously passed or after removal of stone fragments from surgical intervention. This patient has evidence of a large renal stone that is unlikely to pass spontaneously requiring urologic consultation for endoscopic removal or extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.  
❌ Administration of tamsulosin:
Incorrect: Tamsulosin may be provided to patients with confirmed nephrolithiasis unless otherwise contraindicated. However, the best next step in management for this patient is to consult urology given the size of the renal stone.  
❌ Administer potassium citrate:
Incorrect: Potassium citrate is indicated to prevent recurrent stones in patients with uric acid stones. This would be prescribed if 24-hour urine studies and urine microscopy are consistent with  uric acid stones.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting suprapubic discomfort and an inability to urinate for the past eight hours. The patient's medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. The patient smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol socially. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 188/87 mmHg, heart rate is 99 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and shifts frequently in bed. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Suprapubic fullness is noted. Reflexes are normal and symmetric in both upper and lower extremities. Urinalysis and bloodwork are detailed below. Further examination is most likely to reveal which of the following additional findings?

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Sodium      143 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.5 mEq/L    
 Chloride     95 mEq/L    
 BUN     34 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      1.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL 4 weeks ago)    
 Albumin      3.2 g/dL    
 HbA1c     5.8%    
 Urinalysis    
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Blood     Negative    
 Leukocyte esterase     Negative    
 Nitrites     Negative    
 Leukocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Casts     None
questions.solution:
This patient presents with inability to urinate, suprapubic fullness, and laboratory results consistent with acute kidney injury (AKI). Together, these findings indicate acute urinary retention resulting in postrenal AKI. Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the most common cause of acute urinary retention in older adult patients with a prostate, and digital rectal examination often reveals an enlarged, palpable prostate.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined by a sudden decline in kidney function that results in electrolyte imbalances, extracellular dysregulation, and accumulation of nitrogenous wastes such as ammonia and uric acid. Postrenal AKI is a form of AKI caused by obstruction of urine flow anywhere in the urinary tract, leading to increased back pressure and reduced glomerular filtration. It is classified by the level of urinary tract obstruction, either upper or lower.

History and physical examination findings help distinguish the underlying cause of postrenal AKI. Upper urinary tract obstruction (e.g., nephrolithiasis, tumor) typically presents with flank pain, hematuria, and a history of recurrent kidney stones or uropathy. In contrast, lower urinary tract obstruction from BPH often manifests with urinary hesitancy, incomplete bladder emptying, a slow stream, and suprapubic discomfort. On physical examination, findings may include a distended bladder or a palpable prostate on digital rectal examination.

Option Analysis

✅ Enlarged, palpable prostate:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Spasticity:
Incorrect: Neurogenic bladder is a common cause of urinary retention in patients with a known history of neurologic disease (e.g., multiple sclerosis, diabetic neuropathy, spinal cord injury). In this case, the normal reflexes, absence of other neurologic signs, and a well-controlled HbA1c argue against a neurogenic cause. Since benign prostatic hyperplasia is the most common cause of urinary retention in older adults with a prostate, examination would likely reveal an enlarged, palpable prostate.
❌ Costovertebral angle tenderness:
Incorrect: Costovertebral angle tenderness is associated with pyelonephritis or nephrolithiasis. However, these conditions often present with back pain, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and pyuria and/or hematuria on urinalysis. Since benign prostatic hyperplasia is the most common cause of urinary retention in older adults with a prostate, examination would likely reveal an enlarged, palpable prostate.
❌ Palpable hernia:
Incorrect: An incarcerated or strangulated hernia will present with abdominal pain and signs of bowel obstruction (e.g., nausea, vomiting, inability to pass stool or gas). Since benign prostatic hyperplasia is the most common cause of urinary retention in older adults with a prostate, examination would likely reveal an enlarged, palpable prostate.
❌ Bright red blood per rectum:
Incorrect: Bright red blood per rectum indicates lower gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., hemorrhoids, diverticulosis) and is typically unrelated to acute urinary retention. Since benign prostatic hyperplasia is the most common cause of urinary retention in older adults with a prostate, examination would likely reveal an enlarged, palpable prostate.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to a primary care clinic to evaluate urinary symptoms. The patient has been experiencing trouble initiating urination for the past four weeks. The patient has also noticed a poor urinary stream and often felt the bladder was not empty.  A review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 158/89 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Digital rectal examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The patient is started on prazosin. The receptor that this drug works on is attached to which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with obstructive lower urinary tract symptoms, and physical examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth prostate. He most likely has benign prostate hyperplasia. The patient is started on prazosin, which is an α1-adrenergic receptor antagonist. This receptor is coupled with the Gq protein.  

Alpha-adrenergic receptors, ɑ1, and ɑ2 receptors activate when stimulated by catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine). Together, they help to trigger the fight or flight response. ɑ1-receptors are mainly found in the body’s smooth muscles (in the blood vessels, bladder, and other hollow organs) and are stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system. This receptor is coupled with a Gq protein, bound to guanosine diphosphate (GDP) at rest. When an ɑ1-receptor binds a catecholamine, the receptor changes its shape and allows the Gq protein to release GDP and bind guanosine triphosphate (GTP) instead, thereby activating it. This process then triggers a cellular response that leads to smooth musclecontraction.Ɑ1-adrenergic receptor antagonists can inhibit the activation of these receptors (e.g., prazosin, doxazosin, tamsulosin), thereby causing vasodilation and relaxation of the hollow organs (e.g., urinary bladder).  

Option Analysis

✅ G protein with q polypeptide (Gq):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ G inhibitory protein (Gi):
Incorrect: The G inhibitory protein (Gi) is coupled with the α2-adrenergic receptor. Activation of Gi leads to negative feedback on the effects of G stimulating protein (Gs). In contrast, prazosin acts on α1-adrenergic receptors.  
❌ G stimulating protein (Gs):
Incorrect: The G stimulating protein (Gs) is coupled with β-adrenergic receptors, activation of which causes stimulation of various organs of the body (e.g., heart, kidney, skeletal muscles). However, prazosin does not affect β-adrenergic receptors.  
❌ Protein kinase A:
Incorrect: Protein kinase A is an intracellular receptor protein activated by cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). cAMP is produced when β-adrenergic receptors and the coupled G stimulating proteins (Gs) are activated. Prazosin does not affect β-adrenergic receptors.  
❌ Adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: Adenylate cyclase is a cellular enzyme that is activated when β-adrenergic receptors and the coupled G stimulating proteins (Gs) are stimulated. Prazosin does not affect β-adrenergic receptors.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of a weak urinary stream. The symptoms have been gradually worsening for the past six months and now he has to strain to urinate. He has also experienced increased urinary frequency and urgency but has not experienced urinary incontinence or pain with micturition. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history. The patient recalls that his father had similar symptoms in old age. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis results are shown below. Prostate-specific antigen is 5.5 ng/mL. The appropriate treatment of this patient’s condition includes an agent with which of the following mechanisms of action?  

 Laboratory Value  Result
 Urinalysis
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Glucose  negative 
 Blood  negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  negative 
 Nitrites  negative 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf
questions.solution:
The findings of irritative (urinary frequency, urgency) and obstructive symptoms (weak urinary stream and straining on micturition), in combination with a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, non-tender prostate on digital rectal examination (DRE), are suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).  

ɑ1-adrenergic antagonists (e.g., prazosin, terazosin, doxazosin, tamsulosin) are the mainstay of initial treatment for BPH. ɑ1-receptors are found on the smooth muscles of the bladder sphincter, prostate capsule, and prostatic urethra. The inhibition of these receptors by ɑ1-adrenergic antagonists relaxes these smooth muscles and helps relieve bladder outlet obstruction. Other indications for using ɑ1-adrenergic antagonists include

  ●   Hypertension: They can decrease blood pressure by relaxing vascular smooth muscles (except tamsulosin).
  ●   Nightmares associated with post-traumatic stress syndrome (prazosin only).  

Common side effects include 1st dose orthostatic hypotension, dizziness, headaches, and difficulty in ejaculation. Hypotension can be potentiated by concomitant phosphodiesterase (PDE)-5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil).  

Option Analysis

✅ Antagonism of ɑ1-adrenergic receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antagonism of muscarinic cholinergic receptor:
Incorrect: Muscarinic receptors type 3 (M3) are present in the bladder smooth muscles and are responsible for detrusor contractility. Muscarinic antagonists (e.g. oxybutynin) decrease detrusor contractility and are used to manage urge incontinence. These medications are typically avoided in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia as they can exacerbate urinary retention.  
❌ Antagonism of nicotinic cholinergic receptor:
Incorrect: Nicotinic cholinergic receptors are located at the postganglionic neurons in sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia and the neuromuscular junction of skeletal muscle fibers. In general anesthesia, nicotinic antagonists (e.g. tubocurarine) are used to induce paralysis. These medications do not affect bladder or prostate muscle contraction.  
❌ Antagonism of β1-adrenergic receptor:
Incorrect: β1-receptors are located in the heart and juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney. β1-receptor antagonists assist in decreasing heart rate and contractility and inhibit the release of renin, thereby treating hypertension. However, β1-receptor antagonists are not used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.  
❌ Antagonism of ɑ2-adrenergic receptor:
Incorrect: Mirtazapine is a selective ɑ2-adrenergic receptor antagonist used to manage atypical depression. Its mechanism of action involves increasing the release of serotonin and norepinephrine. However, ɑ2-adrenergic receptor antagonists are not used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department because he has been unable to void urine for the past 12 hours and has suprapubic pain. He returned home yesterday after outpatient laparoscopic shoulder surgery. The patient reports a history of recurrent urinary retention due to an enlarged prostate. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 177/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 101/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears uncomfortable. Abdominal examination reveals suprapubic fullness and tenderness. Rectal exam is significant for an enlarged prostate and normal anal sphincter tone. Bladder scan reveals >1L.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy presents with acute urinary retention following an outpatient surgical procedure. The immediate treatment of acute urinary retention is foley catheter placement to decompress the bladder and relieve pain.

For patients who present with acute urinary retention, immediate decompression of the bladder with a foley catheter or suprapubic catheter should be performed to relieve pain. Then further evaluation should be undertaken to determine the underlying etiology and address it accordingly. Patients with evidence of an enlarged prostate can be treated with alpha blockers or PDE inhibitors to relieve symptoms. When urinary retention is caused by urinary infection, it should be treated with appropriate antibiotic therapy. If a causative medication is identified (e.g. diphenhydramine or other antimuscarinic agents) it should be discontinued. Patients with urinary retention secondary to cauda equina syndrome or spinal cord lesions require immediate surgical intervention.  

Option Analysis

✅ Insert a foley catheter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer tamsulosin:
Incorrect: This patient should first have a foley catheter placed to immediately relieve his pain. Tamsulosin can relieve symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia within days.  
❌ Administer intravenous fluids:
Incorrect:  Administration of intravenous fluids is likely to worsen this patient's symptoms of urinary retention.  
❌ Administer morphine:
Incorrect: While analgesia can help relieve this patient's discomfort, a foley catheter should be placed to immediately address the urinary retention and relieve pain. Additionally opioids can induce urinary retention and should be avoided.  
❌ Insert a suprapubic catheter:
Incorrect:  A suprapubic catheter should only be placed for urinary retention if straight catheterization or foley catheter placement cannot be performed or are unsuccessful.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right flank pain and hematuria that began suddenly that morning. The pain is intense and lasts for about 30 minutes before it resolves, and then it comes on again. She has no past medical history and is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 156/65 mm Hg, heart rate is 88/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On initial assessment, the patient appears uncomfortable and is vomiting into an emesis basin. On abdominal examination, there is mild distension and no abdominal tenderness, rebound, or guarding. There is right flank tenderness upon palpation. Urinalysis shows hematuria. The patient is started on IV normal saline and laboratory studies are pending. Point-of-care pregnancy screening is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and physical examination findings (e.g. flank tenderness) consistent with nephrolithiasis. Additionally, urinalysis shows hematuria. The best next step in management is to provide pain control with an IV nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, such as ketorolac. Then a non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Nephrolithiasis, also known as renal calculi or renal stones, is a painful condition where crystals form in the kidney, potentially causing urinary tract obstruction.  Renal stones usually form when urine becomes oversaturated with minerals and salts, including calcium, oxalate, and uric acid. Common renal stone types include calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate, uric acid, cystine, and struvite stones. Patients typically  present with acute onset severe flank pain that waxes and wanes. It is typically associated with hematuria, nausea, and vomiting; and urgency and dysuria may be seen.

The acute management of patients with suspected nephrolithiasis includes an ABCDE assessment and stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. Additionally, IV access should be obtained, and continuous vital sign monitoring, IV fluids, IV analgesia, and antiemetic therapy should be initiated. Basic blood work and urinalysis should be performed followed by appropriate imaging to confirm the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV ketorolac:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV morphine:
Incorrect:  Opioids, like morphine, can be used for pain control in nephrolithiasis. However, they should be reserved for patients who have contraindications to NSAIDs or have insufficient pain control on NSAIDs.  
❌ Administer oral acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is an analgesic and antipyretic. While it can provide pain relief, it is not as effective as IV NSAIDs or opioids for the severe pain often associated with nephrolithiasis. Additionally, vomiting may limit the effectiveness of oral medications in this patient.  
❌ Administer oral ibuprofen:
Incorrect:  Ibuprofen is an NSAID that can be effective in managing pain associated with nephrolithiasis. However, vomiting may limit the effectiveness of oral medications in this patient.  
❌ Administer oral oxycodone:
Incorrect:  Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic that can provide pain relief in cases of nephrolithiasis when NSAIDs are contraindicated or insufficient. However, the patient’s vomiting may limit the effectiveness of oral medications.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of severe left flank pain for the past week. The pain has an intermittent squeezing quality, radiates to the groin, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. The patient does not have abdominal pain or fever.  Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows severe left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness and urine dipstick reveals microscopic hematuria. Urinalysis shows crystals in the shape of an envelope. The patient is started on a medication that decreases urinary calcium excretion. Which of the following segments of the nephron is affected by this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with flank pain, hematuria, and envelope-shaped stones on urinalysis most likely have calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis. Thiazide diuretics decrease calcium excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and are an effective treatment option for prevention.

Thiazides inhibit sodium chloride transport by apical Na-Cl cotransporters by competing for a chloride site on the transporter, in the early segment of the distal convoluted tubule. Although thiazides inhibit the reabsorption of sodium in this segment, they increase the reabsorption of calcium. Moreover, calcium reabsorption is also increased along the proximal tubule as a result of reduced extracellular fluid volume, which enhances proximal reabsorption. 

In addition, thiazides are also known to decrease serum magnesium levels. Hypomagnesemia has been suggested to result from potassium deficiency, increased passive magnesium secretion, or decreased active magnesium transport in the distal convoluted tubule. 

Loop diuretics, on the other hand, can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia by decreasing the electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increasing urinary magnesium and calcium excretion.   

Option Analysis

❌ A :
Incorrect: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, blocking NaHCO3, and water reabsorption and resulting in urinary bicarbonate wasting. It does not decrease urinary calcium excretion. 
❌ B:
Incorrect: The descending loop of Henle carries fluid from the proximal tubule to the ascending loop of Henle. It allows reabsorption of water into the interstitial fluids to produce concentrated urine. No known drug effectively acts on this segment of the nephron. 
❌ C:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter and can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia by decreasing the electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increasing urinary magnesium and calcium excretion. 
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ E:
Incorrect: Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act on the collecting duct systems. They do not affect urine calcium excretion.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with four hours of suprapubic pressure and difficulty initiating urination. Medical history is significant only for seasonal allergies, which are currently managed with over-the-counter diphenhydramine. The patient does not drink alcohol or use tobacco products. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 160/87 mmHg, heart rate is 101 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 35 kg/m². On physical examination, there is mild left costovertebral angle tenderness. The suprapubic region is soft without a palpable mass and shows only minimal tenderness on deep palpation. Cardiopulmonary and the remainder of the abdominal exam are unremarkable. Initial laboratory studies show a creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL (baseline 0.7 mg/dL). Which of the following additional tests is most likely to quickly delineate the anatomic region of pathology?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of urinary retention in the setting of active diphenhydramine use, and laboratory studies confirm acute kidney injury (AKI). The next step in evaluating suspected postrenal AKI is to distinguish upper-tract from lower-tract obstruction. A bedside post-void residual (PVR) bladder scan rapidly confirms whether urine is being retained in the bladder, signifying a lower-tract process.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) refers to a sudden decline in kidney function that results in electrolyte imbalances, extracellular dysregulation, and accumulation of nitrogenous wastes such as ammonia and uric acid. It is diagnosed by a rise in serum creatinine, and urinalysis is typically used to screen for intrinsic renal disease, infection, or hematuria. Postrenal AKI results from urinary outflow obstruction, which increases intraluminal pressure and reduces glomerular filtration; classification as upper (ureteral) versus lower (bladder/urethral) obstruction helps narrow the differential.

Once postrenal AKI is suspected, a post-void residual (PVR) bladder scan quantifies the residual volume of urine and is a key fork in the diagnostic pathway. A PVR ≥100 mL indicates lower urinary tract obstruction and warrants immediate catheterization. Further imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT) or cystoscopy may be indicated if a bladder outlet obstruction or urethral obstruction are suspected. History and physical examination may also reveal clues about the etiology in cases of benign prostatic hypertrophy, neurogenic bladder, or medication-induced urinary retention (e.g. use of medications with anticholinergic properties, such as diphenhydramine in this case). In contrast, a PVR <100 mL suggests an upper urinary tract etiology and should prompt CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis to identify nephrolithiasis, malignancy, or intrabdominal abscess.

Option Analysis

✅ Post-void residual bladder scan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: While a CT can identify many causes for urinary obstruction (e.g., ureteral stones, masses), it takes longer to obtain, costs more, exposes the patient to ionizing radiation, and may be unnecessary for cases of straightforward medication-induced urinary retention. As a result, a CT is typically reserved as a second‑line study, used only if additional information is needed after a quick post-void bladder scan has determined whether urinary retention is present.
❌ Serum blood urea nitrogen (BUN):
Incorrect: A serum BUN helps calculate the BUN:Creatinine ratio, but it does not localize an obstruction to the upper versus lower urinary tract, which is the main concern in this vignette. Instead, this can quickly and easily be determined with a post-void bladder scan.
❌ Urinalysis :
Incorrect: A urinalysis is useful in evaluating for the presence of infection, hematuria, proteinuria, or casts. However, it does not determine whether urinary obstruction is from an upper or a lower urinary tract process, which is the main concern in this vignette. Instead, this can quickly and easily be determined with a post-void bladder scan.
❌ Renal biopsy:
Incorrect: A renal biopsy is an invasive test reserved for the diagnosis of intrinsic kidney disease (e.g. glomerular disease). It does not determine whether urinary obstruction is from an upper or a lower urinary tract process. Instead, this can quickly and easily be determined with a post-void bladder scan.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the office due to issues with urination, which have been ongoing for the past year. He has experienced urinary frequency and urgency but has not had pain with micturition. He also has occasional headaches but is otherwise healthy. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. Family history is essential for prostate cancer in his grandfather. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Digital rectal examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The rest of the physical exam is noncontributory. Urinalysis results are shown below. The patient is started on tamsulosin for management of his symptoms. Which of the following best describes the effect of tamsulosin in this patient?  

 Laboratory Value  Result
 Urinalysis
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Glucose  negative 
 Blood  negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  negative 
 Nitrites  negative 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf

choices.text: Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  Decrease No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  Decrease  No change  No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  change No change  Decrease  No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  Relax

questions.solution:
This patient has irritative symptoms (urinary frequency, urgency), and physical examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth prostate with a rubbery texture. These findings are suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). He is prescribed tamsulosin, an ɑ1-adrenergic antagonist, to treat his lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).  

ɑ1-adrenergic antagonists are mainly used to improve bladder outlet obstruction by relaxing smooth muscles in the bladder sphincter, prostate capsule, and prostatic urethra. Tamsulosin, however, is different from other drugs in this class (doxazosin, prazosin, terazosin) in that it specifically acts against α1A and α1D receptors (subtypes of alpha-1 receptors) found in the smooth muscle of the bladder neck and prostate. It does not affect ɑ1-receptors in peripheral blood vessels and cannot treat hypertension. Moreover, the medication is known to cause relaxation of the iris dilator muscle and is associated with intraoperative floppy iris syndrome (IFIS).  

Option Analysis

✅  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  No effect :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  Decrease No effect :
Incorrect: ɑ1-adrenergic antagonists (e.g. prazosin) play a major role in the relaxation of the bladder neck, prostate capsule, and prostatic urethra. These medications can also relax vascular smooth muscle and decrease blood pressure. In contrast, tamsulosin is a selective ɑ1a-receptor antagonist that acts on only the bladder neck muscles. As a result, tamsulosin would not cause a decrease in blood pressure.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  Decrease  No change  No effect :
Incorrect: Finasteride, a 5ɑ-reductase inhibitor, decreases the prostate volume by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It also helps decrease the LUTS in benign prostatic hyperplasia. However, this patient was started on tamsulosin, which does not affect prostate volume.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  change No change  Decrease  No effect :
Incorrect: This patient was started on tamsulosin, which is a selective ɑ1a-receptor antagonist that acts on only the bladder, neck muscles. As a result, tamsulosin would not cause a decrease in blood pressure.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  Relax:
